selected_quotes: A Retrospective Analysis of Ki-67 Index and its Prognostic Significance in Over 800 Primary Breast… #breastcancer

citation.abstract:
The Ki-67 index is chiefly important for distinguishing between luminal A and luminal B human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2neu)-negative breast cancer subtypes. However, its ability to predict response to chemotherapy is uncertain.
Patients treated for primary breast cancer at the University Hospital of Cologne were identified. Immunohistochemistry for Ki-67 detection was performed according to standard protocols. Kaplan-Meier survival curves were calculated and compared using the log-rank test.
Patients with low Ki-67 index had a significantly better disease-free-survival (DFS) than patients with high Ki-67 index (hazard ratio=2.85; 95% confidence interval=1.45-5.59; p=0.002). A significant influence on DFS was demonstrated (hazard ratio(HR)=1.02; confidence interval(CI)=1.00-1.04; p=0.048) within the subgroup of hormone receptor-positive and HER2neu-negative patients, but not within the subgroup of those with luminal B/HER2neu-negative tumors (DFS: p=0.801; overall-survival: p=0.379).
The Ki-67 index has a prognostic impact on DFS in patients with hormone receptor-positive and HER2neu-negative tumors. The strict cut-off value was not suitable for distinguishing between high- and low-risk patients and their response to adjuvant chemotherapy.
